TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Medial-skeletal, amorphic, frigid Humic Haploxerands

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Tater medial coarse sandy loam - ponderosa pine/Saskatoon serviceberry/Idaho fescue plant community - woodland, on a 1 percent slope at 4,200 feet elevation.  (Colors are for moist soil unless otherwise noted.)
Oi--0 to 1 inch; slightly decomposed plant material; forest litter of needles, twigs, cones and herbaceous material; abrupt smooth boundary.  (0 to 1 inch thick)
A1--1 to 4 inches; very dark brown (10YR 2/2) medial coarse sandy loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) dry; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; many very fine, fine and medium and common coarse, and  very coarse roots; many very fine irregular pores; 5 percent indurated volcanic rock gravel; moderately acid (pH 6.0); abrupt smooth boundary.  (2 to 8 inches thick)
A2--4 to 16 inches; very dark brown (10YR 2/2) gravelly medial coarse sandy loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) dry; weak medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; many very fine, fine and medium and common coarse and very coarse roots; common fine irregular pores; 20 percent indurated volcanic rock gravel, 5 percent indurated volcanic rock cobbles and 5 percent indurated volcanic rock stones; slightly acid (pH 6.2); diffuse wavy boundary.  (12 to 28 inches thick)
BA--16 to 28 inches; dark brown (10YR 3/3) extremely cobbly medial sandy loam, brown (10YR 5/3) dry; weak medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky, nonplastic; many very fine, fine and medium and common coarse and very coarse roots; many fine irregular pores; 30 percent indurated volcanic rock gravel, 20 percent indurated volcanic rock cobbles and 10 percent indurated volcanic rock stones; slightly acid (pH 6.4); clear smooth boundary.  (6 to 20 inches thick)
2Bq--28 to 63 inches; brown (10YR 4/3) extremely cobbly ashy coarse sand, light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) dry; massive; moderately hard, friable, nonsticky, nonplastic; many fine and common very fine roots; many fine irregular pores; 10 percent silica bridging sand grains; 40 percent indurated volcanic rock gravel, 30 percent indurated volcanic rock cobbles and 10 percent indurated volcanic rock stones; slightly acid (pH 6.4).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Klamath County, Oregon; about 10 miles south and 16 miles west of Chiloquin; 2000 feet east and 1900 feet north of the southwest corner of section 18, T. 36 S., R. 6 E., Lake of the Woods N., Oregon USGS quadrangle.  UTM:  569051 meters E; 4698342 meters N; Zone 10 N. NAD27 CONUS datum. Latitude:  42 degrees 26 minutes 11.00 seconds north, Longitude:  122 degrees  9 minutes 38.00 seconds west.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Soil temperature regime: frigid
Mean annual soil temperature: 41 to 47 degrees F
Soil moisture regime: xeric. Moisture control section - 8 to 24 inches, dry in all parts for 45 to 60 days in August, September or October
Diagnostic horizons and features:
Umbric epipedon: 20 to 40 inches thick
Base saturation by sum of bases throughout the profile: 3 to 15 percent
Andic soil properties: from the mineral soil surface to 63 inches
Upper part (A and BA horizons): Volcanic glass 10 to 30 percent, Al+1/2Fe 2.5 to 5.0, P-retention 85 to 100, 15 bar water dry 20 to 30.  Oxalate extractable silica is 1.5 to 2.0 percent.
Lower part (2Bq horizon): Volcanic glass 10 to 30 percent, Al+1/2Fe 1.0 to 2.5, P-retention 50 to 70, 15 bar water dry 5 to 10.  Oxalate extractable silica is 0.9 to 1.5 percent.
Depth to lithologic discontinuity (2Bq horizon): 20 to 40 inches
Particle-size control section from 1 to 41 inches: 1 to 28 inches medial-skeletal with rock fragments averaging 40 to 60 percent, 28 to 41 inches ashy-skeletal with rock fragments averaging 50 to 80 percent
A1 horizon
Hue:  7.5YR or 10YR moist or dry
Value:  2 or 2.5 moist, 3 or 4 dry
Chroma:  2 or 3 moist or dry
Gravel content:  5 to 15 percent
Cobble content:  0 to 10 percent
Stone content:  0 to 5 percent
Clay content: 2 to 10 percent
Reaction:  moderately acid or slightly acid (pH 5.6 to 6.5)
Organic matter: 10 to 20 percent
A2 horizon
Hue:  7.5YR or 10YR moist or dry
Value:  2 or 3 moist, 3 or 4 dry
Chroma:  2 or 3 moist or dry
Texture:  medial sandy loam, medial coarse sandy loam, gravelly medial coarse sandy loam
Gravel content:  5 to 20 percent
Cobble content:  0 to 10 percent
Stone content:  0 to 5 percent
Clay content: 2 to 10 percent
Reaction:  moderately acid or slightly acid (pH 5.6 to 6.5)
Organic matter: 8 to 15 percent
BA horizon
Value:  2 or 3 moist, 4 or 5 dry
Chroma:  2 or 3 moist or dry
Texture: very cobbly medial sandy loam, extremely cobbly medial sandy loam, very cobbly medial coarse sandy loam, extremely cobbly medial coarse sandy loam
Gravel content:  10 to 50 percent
Cobble content:  10 to 30 percent
Stone content:  0 to 10 percent
Clay content: 2 to 10 percent
Reaction:  moderately acid or slightly acid (pH 5.6 to 6.5)
Organic matter: 3 to 8 percent
2Bq horizon
Depth to:  20 to 40 in
Hue:  10YR moist or dry
Value:  4 to 6 moist, 5 to 7 dry
Chroma:  3 to 6 moist, 3 or 4 dry
Texture:  very cobbly ashy coarse sand, very cobbly ashy loamy coarse sand, extremely cobbly ashy coarse sand, extremely cobbly ashy loamy coarse sand
Gravel content:  30 to 40 percent
Cobble content:  20 to 40 percent
Stone content:  0 to 15 percent
Clay content: 0 to 7 percent
Reaction:  moderately acid or slightly acid (pH 5.6 to 6.5)
Organic matter; 0.5 to 1.0 percent

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Juniperlake and McNair series.  Juniperlake soils are 40 to 60 inches deep to a densic contact.  McNair soils are 40 to 60 inches deep to a paralithic contact.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content:
GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:
Landscape - Cascade Mountains
Landform - outwash fans on mountain valleys
Elevation - 4,130 to 4,300 feet
Slope - 1 to 4 percent
Parent material - alluvium derived from volcanic rock or tephra
Climate - cold wet winters, cool dry summers
Mean annual air temperature - 39 to 45 degrees F
Mean annual precipitation - 22 to 30 inches
Frost-free period - less than 100 days

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Anniecreek, Hoxie, Pokegema and Woodcock soils.  Anniecreek soils are somewhat poorly drained, have an irregular decrease in organic carbon with depth and have redoximorphic accumulations beginning at depths of 20 to 40 inches.  Hoxie soils are poorly drained and have less than 15 percent rock fragments in the particle-size control section.  Pokegema soils are well drained and have less than 35 percent rock fragments in the lower portion of the particle-size control section.  Woodcock soils are well drained and have an argillic horizon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content:
DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:
Drainage - well drained
Permeability - moderately rapid over very rapid

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Tater soils are used for gravel and sand quarries, timber production, wildlife habitat, watershed and recreation.  The present vegetation consists of forested communities with a canopy of ponderosa pine and widely dispersed white fir over a shrub component with variable structure and cover dominated by Saskatoon serviceberry or antelope bitterbrush and an herbaceous component with light to moderate cover dominated by Idaho fescue.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Klamath County, Oregon; MLRA 21.  Series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE:  Portland, Oregon

ORIGIN.content: SERIES PROPOSED:  Winema National Forest, Klamath County, Oregon, 2008

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:
Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:
Umbric epipedon - 1 to 28 inches (A1, A2 and BA horizons)
Andic soil properties present through out the profile.
Particle-size control section - 1 to 41 inches, with 1 to 28 inches being medial-skeletal and amorphic, and 28 to 41 inches being ashy-skeletal and amorphic.  Classification is based on the thickest part (medial-skeletal and amorphic).  Need to propose a contrasting particle-size class of medial-skeletal over ashy-skeletal with 15 bar water qualifying statement the same as used in the medial over ashy contrasting particle size class family.
ADDITIONAL DATA:
NSSL data from the OSD typical pedon S08OR035005.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
